title: Infimum and supremum
summary: In mathematics, the infimum (abbreviated inf; plural infima) of a subset S {\displaystyle S} of a partially ordered set P {\displaystyle P} is a greatest element in P {\displaystyle P} that is less than or equal to each element of S , {\displaystyle S,} if such an element exists.[1]  Consequently, the term greatest lower bound (abbreviated as GLB) is also commonly used.[1] The supremum (abbreviated sup; plural suprema) of a subset S {\displaystyle S} of a partially ordered set P {\displaystyle P} is the least element in P {\displaystyle P} that is greater than or equal to each element of S , {\displaystyle S,} if such an element exists.[1] Consequently, the supremum is also referred to as the least upper bound (or LUB).[1]
